Preparation and characterization of nano-TiO2/
chitosan/poly(N-isopropylacrylamide) composite hydrogel and its application for
removal of ionic dyes
Jianhua Zhoua,b*, Bianzhi Haoa, Linben Wanga, Jianzhong Maa,b
a College of Bioresources Chemistry and Materials Engineering, Shaanxi University of Science and Technology, Xi’an 710021, China b Shaanxi Research Institute of Agricultural Products Processing Technology, Xi’an 710021, China.
Corresponding Author *Corresponding author. Tel.: +86-029-86132559-609; Fax: +86-029-86132559-603.
E-mail addresses: zhoujianh@21cn.com(J. H. Zhou)
ABSTRACT
Nano-TiO2/chitosan/poly(N-isopropylacrylamide) (nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm) composite hydrogel was prepared by a two-step polymerization method, and nano-TiO2 was used to give the photocatalytic activity of the composite hydrogel. The nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel was characterized by FT-IR and SEM. And its adsorption and photocatalytic degradation were investigated. The results indicated that dye adsorption was strongly influenced by solution pH and the acid fuchsin (AF) removal rate was maximum at pH=4. The composite hydrogel exhibited slightly decreased dye removal rate with increasing temperature, and the composite hydrogel containing AF dyes floated on the solution surface at 40 and could be readily removed from the aqueous solution. Kinetics analysis indicated that the dye adsorption by nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel obeyed pseudo-second order model. Moreover, nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel exhibited high efficiency of photocatalytic degradation for AF dyes, and AF dye removal rate reached 90.5% under UV irradiation for 160 min. Keywords: Composite hydrogel, Nano-TiO2, poly(N-isopropylacrylamide), Acid fuchsin, Photocatalytic activity

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Hydrogels are crosslinked hydrophilic polymers, swelling extensively in water[1], which find wide application in drug delivery & tissue engineering[2], agriculture & horticulture[3] and wastewaters remediation[4,5]. In wastewaters remediation, hydrogels have been investigated as an adsorbent for the removal of dyes and heavy metal. Chitosan is a non-toxic, biocompatible and biodegradable polysaccharide derived from chitin. Chitosan-based hydrogels containing numerous hydrophilic functional groups would be effective for adsorption of polar organic molecules such as synthetic dyes from water[6,7]. Although chitosan-based hydrogels have many advantages as an adsorbent for dyes wastewater, the properties such as the removal of dyes and chemical stability of hydrogels need to be further improved for practical applications. Attempts have been made to modify the properties of hydrogels by the incorporation of nano- and micro-particles of inorganic materials into the polymer networks without decreasing their swelling ability[8,9].
TiO2 is a non-expensive, non-toxic, biocompatible photocatalyst, with good chemical stability and high reactivity, and TiO2 photocatalysis technique has been used in the degradation of toxic substance and dyes in wastewater[10]. Chitosan-based hydrogels containing nano-TiO2 used for photocatalytic degradation of dyes attracts a great deal of attention in wastewater remediation[11,12]. They are designed by immobilization of nano-TiO2 on matrix, which have an enhanced photocatalytic efficiency and large surface area to enrich dilute pollutants and solve the difficulty of separation nano-TiO2 from the aqueous solution after post-processing.
Tao et al[13] investigated the adsorption of Pb(II) from aqueous solution using chitosan/TiO2 hybrid polymer adsorbent, which exhibited high adsorption capacity for Pb(II) removal. Zhu et al[14] reported that CdS/TiO2/chitosan composite could be used as a suitable and promising photocatalyst for effective decolorization treatment of dyes-containing effluents. It is well known that thermosensitive hydrogels show reversible phase transition associated with a change in hydrophobicity at the low critical solution temperature (LCST), which can be useful for the collection and removal of organic pollutants in wastewater[15]. However, to the best of our knowledge, research work concerning the removal of dyes using chitosan-based thermosensitive hydrogel containing nano-TiO2 has not been presented previously.
In this study, nano-TiO2/chitosan/poly(N-isopropylacrylamide) (nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm) composite hydrogel was successfully prepared, in an attempt to photocatalyze degradation of ionic dyes (acid fuchsin as a model dyes). The nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel was characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra. The effect of the pH of dyes solution on the removal of dyes, effect of solution temperature on removal of dyes and adsorption kinetics at different initial dyes concentrations were investigated. The photocatalytic activity of the composite hydrogel was evaluated in the dye degradation under UV irradiation.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials.
sections.text:
Chitosan (CS) (deacetylation degree＞90%) was purchased from Yuanju Biological
Technology Co., Ltd., China. N-isopropylacrylamide (NIPAAm) and N,N'-methylenebisacrylamide (MBA) were purchased from Titan Scientific Co.,Ltd., China and Kermel Chemical Reagent Co.,Ltd., China, respectively, and used without further purification. Modified nano-TiO2 containing double bond (anatase, the particle diameter of 20 nm) was supplied from Wan Jing New Material Co., Ltd., China. Ammonium persulphate (APS) was obtained from Xi'an Chemical Reagent Factory, China. N,N,N',N'-Tetramethylethylenediamine (TEMED) was obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., China. Acid fuchsin (AF, C20H17N3Na2O9S3) supplied from Tianxin Fine Chemical Development Center in China was used as a model pollutant and the chemical structure was presented in Chart 1.

2.2 Preparation of nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel.
The preparation procedure of nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel is presented as below. Firstly, 0.15 g of CS was dissolved in 10 mL of 1% acetic acid aqueous solution under stirring for 24 h. 0.5g of NIPAAm, 0.05g of MBA and 0.05g of modified nano-TiO2 were mixed with CS aqueous solution in 100 mL three-necked reactor and sonicated for 10 min to improve the dispersion of modified nano-TiO2 nanoparticles, and then the mixture was purged with Argon for 30min. Subsequently,
0.015g APS and 0.03 mL TEMED were added and the whole mixture was magnetically stirred about 1h at 20℃ for initial polymerization. After the initial polymerization was finished, the second step polymerization was performed at -18℃ for 24 h, namely freezing polymerization17,18. Finally, the composite hydrogel was immersed in water for 24 h to wash out any soluble polymers, unreacted monomers and the initiator. Thereafter, it was freeze-dried in a LGJ-10C lyophilizer (at -50℃ and 0.045 mbar) for 24 h.

sections.heading: 2.3 Characterizations.
sections.text: Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a FT-IR spectrometer (BRUKER Avance VECTOR-22, Germany), using KBr pellet made by mixing KBr with fine powder of the sample. The surface morphology and internal structure of the dried composite hydrogel was observed by scanning electron microscope (SEM, S-3400N, Hitachi, Japan).

sections.heading: 2.4 Adsorption Studies.
sections.text:
Nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel was used as adsorbent for the removal of AF dyes. Adsorption tests of AF dyes by nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel were carried out in a temperature-controlled incubator shaker set at 150 rpm and maintained at 20 ℃ for 4 h. Firstly, 0.02 g of dried nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel was thoroughly mixed with 15 mL of AF dyes solution in sample bottle. After sample bottles were shaken for the desired time, the suspensions were collected and filtered through Whatman 0.45 µm filter paper. The filtrates were analyzed for the dyes concentration by using a UV-vis
spectrophotometer (UV5200, Shanghai Metash Instruments Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China) at the wavelength of 546 nm.

sections.heading: 2.5 Photocatalyze removal of dyes under UV irradiation.
sections.text: The photocatalytic activity of nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel was evaluated by photocatalytic degradation of AF dyes with a UV lamp (365 nm, 300 W) at 25℃. In a typical run, 0.02 g of nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel was added to 50 mL of AF dyes aqueous solution (10 mg/L), and then illuminated with UV lamp. Sample for analysis (about 4 mL) was taken and the filtrate was analyzed on a UV-vis spectrophotometer at 546 nm for AF solution. The dye removal rate was calculated using the equation (3).

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
3.1 Synthesis and Characterization of nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite
hydrogel
Nano-TiO2/chitosan/poly(N-isopropylacrylamide) (nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm) composite hydrogel was synthesized by a two-step polymerization method, the initial polymerization being carried out at 20 for 1 h, followed by polymerization at -18 for 24 h, as shown in Scheme 1. The redox initiator system used consisted of ammonium persulphate (APS) and N,N,N',N'-Tetramethylethylenediamine (TEMED). N,N'-methylenebisacrylamide (MBA) as a crosslinking agent can react with NIPAAm and modified nano-TiO2 containing carbon-carbon double bonds in the presence of CS to form a network type composite hydrogel. The obtained network type composite hydrogel allows dye molecules to enter into the interior of the composite hydrogel more easily and fast.
Scheme1. Schematic illustration for the synthesis of nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite
hydrogel.
Fig. 1 shows the FT-IR spectrum of nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel.
The peak at 2973 cm-1 results from methyl(-CH3) groups stretching vibration of isopropyl groups (-CH(CH3)2). The amide-I band at 1643cm -1 and the amide-II band at 1546cm-1 are ascribed to the carbonyl stretching vibration and the N-H bending vibration of the secondary amide group(-CONH-), respectively[16]. These observations provide evidences for the presence of PNIPAAm in nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel. The peak at 1079 cm -1 is due to C-O stretching of ring ether of CS, which indicates that CS is immobilized onto matrix[19,20]. The peak at 645 cm-1 is ascribed to Ti-O stretching vibration[21], indicating the incorporation of modified nano-TiO2 nanoparticle into the nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel.
Fig. 1 FT-IR spectrum of nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel.
The surface morphology of dried nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel was observed by SEM, as shown in Fig. 2. Obviously, it has a porous structure with the pore size of about 40µm[22]. Furthermore, the pores in nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm
composite hydrogel are connected with each other to form open channels, which remarkably facilitate the migration of water and dyes moleculars inside the composite hydrogel[23].
Fig. 2 Surface morphology of the nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel.
3.2 Adsorption Studies

sections.heading: 3.2.1 Effect of solution pH on dye removal
sections.text:
The pH of dye solution is an important parameter affecting adsorption capacity of the hydrogels containing chitosan[6,24]. Fig. 3 shows the effect of the pH of dye solution on the removal of dyes by nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel at the initial dye concentration of 50 mg/L. The dye removal rate on nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel increases with the increase of the solution pH from 1.0 to 4.0, and thereafter decreases when the solution pH increases further from 4.0 to 7.0. The maximum dye removal rate is 72.4 % at pH 4.
Fig. 3 Effect of the pH of dyes solution on AF dye removal rate by nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel at 20℃.
The effect of solution pH on dye removal rate can be related to the degree of the
protonation of amino groups in the composite hydrogel and the dissociation of AF dye. When AF dye is dissolved in an aqueous solution, its containing sulfonate groups (-SO3Na) become dissociated and converted into anionic (-SO3 - ). The primary amino groups existing in nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel become protonated (-NH3 +) in the presence of H+. In this case, strong electrostatic attraction exists between the anionic AF dyes and -NH3 + groups on the composite hydrogel. Nevertheless, this interaction can be affected by the change of pH value in the system. The lower dye removal rate at an excessively low pH (pH<4) can be explained as follows. The anionic sulfonic groups (-SO3 - ) of AF dyes will be converted into -SO3H in strong acidic solution. Thereafter, the density of negative charges of dyes is reduced, weakening dyes’ binding with nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel. With the increase of pH, the degree of ionization of -SO3H increases and so does the density of
negative charges of AF dyes, so the amount of dyes adsorbed on the composite hydorgel increases, leading to the increase of the dye removal rate. However, when solution pH is above the optimum value (pH>4), the number of protonated -NH2 groups of the composite hydrogel decreases, therefore the dye removal rate decreases with the increase of solution pH[20]. As a result, the pH of dye solution is one of the dominant parameters affecting the adsorption of AF dyes onto nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel, implying that the dominant role for AF dyes adsorption onto the composite hydrogel is electrostatic attraction.

sections.heading: 3.2.2 Effect of solution temperature on dye removal
sections.text:
Generally speaking, the dye adsorption is an exothermic process and the physical bonding between dyes and the active sites of the composite hydrogel will be affected by solution temperature[25]. In this study, the removal rate of AF dyes from aqueous solutions by nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel at 20℃, 30 and 40 were studied, as shown in Fig. 4. It can be seen that the dye removal rate slightly decreases with increasing temperature, indicating that the adsorption of AF dyes on nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel is an exothermic process. The decrease of removal rate can be attributed to the gradual hydrogen bond weakening with increasing temperature between amino groups in AF dyes and the hydrophilic groups (-NH2, -OH and –CONH-) in nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel 26. In addition, compared with the composite hydrogel at 20℃ which is in the swollen state and deposited in the bottom of the sample bottle, the composite hydrogel at 40℃ shows a shrunken state and floated on the solution surface. This phenomenon can be
attributed to the hydrophilic-hydrophobic transition when temperature increases above the lower critical solution temperature(LCST, ~32℃) of PNIPAAm driven by a reduced amount of structured water around hydrophobic groups[27-29], which promotes the hydrophobic interactions between the polymers. Furthermore, the shrunken composite hydrogel containing AF dyes could be collected which is readily removed from the aqueous solution.
Fig. 4 Effect of the temperature of dye solution on AF dye removal rate by nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel at pH 4.

In this study, the dye adsorption capacity of nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel at various time intervals was studied at pH 4, as represented in Fig. 5. The amount of AF dyes adsorbed rises with increasing time until AF dye adsorption reaches saturation. Meanwhile, it also shows that the amount of AF dyes adsorbed rises as concentration increases and adsorption equilibrium is attained at a much faster rate for lower AF dye concentration. The plots of log (qe-qt) versus t and t/qt versus t for AF dye adsorption onto nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel are drawn in Fig. 6 (a) and (b), respectively. The kinetic parameters (k1, k2, qe, c) and correlation coefficients (R2) are calculated, as shown in Tab 1. The calculated equilibrium adsorption value (q1e,cal) based on pseudo-first-order kinetics is significantly different from the experimental equilibrium values (qe) and the correlation coefficients R 2 are also found to be lower. These results show that the pseudo-first-order kinetic model does not well describe the adsorption of AF dyes on nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel. However, the values of the correlation coefficient (R2) for the pseudo-second-order kinetic model are up to 0.99 and the adsorption capacities
calculated by the model (q2e,cal) are closer to experimental values (qe). The analysis of results indicates chemical adsorption involving electrostatic interaction between dyes molecules and the composite hydrogel functions as rate controlling step[19,20].

sections.heading: 3.3 Photocatalytic activity of the nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel
sections.text:
The photocatalytic activity of nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel was studied under UV irradiation, as shown in Fig. 7. It is observed that the AF dye removal rate under UV irradiation is higher than that in dark. The removal rate of AF dyes increases from 64.02% to 90.80% when the reaction vessel is exposed under UV irradiation from 60 min to 150 min, while it shows the negligible dye degradation efficiency in dark. It is clear that nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel is more effective in the removal of dyes under UV irradiation compared to that in dark. The higher photocatalytic degradation under the UV light irradiation is contributed to effective photocatalytic activity of the well-distributed TiO2 in nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel. It is well established that upon UV irradiation on the surface of the TiO2 immobilized in nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel, electron (e−) and hole (h+) pairs are generated. The photogenerated holes will be reacted with water to form hydroxyl radicals (·OH) which are extremely reactive and can oxidize the AF dyes to form oxidation products[11,21]. Therefore, nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel has a promising application in treatment of dyes containing effluents.
Fig. 7 Removal rate of AF dyes by nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel under different experimental conditions: (a) under UV irradiation, (b) in dark.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
Nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel was prepared by a two-step polymerization method for the removal of AF dyes from aqueous solution. The FT-IR indicated that nano-TiO2 was immobilized in the nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel. The composite hydrogel was numerous micro-porous according to the SEM observations. The dye removal rate by nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel increased with the increase of the solution pH from 1.0 to 4.0 and thereafter decreased, implying that the dominant role between the dyes and the composite hydrogel was electrostatic attraction. The composite hydrogel exhibited slightly decreased dye removal rate with increasing temperature, indicating that the adsorption of AF dyes on nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel was an exothermic process. The adsorption process of the AF dyes on nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel
followed the pseudo second-order kinetic model. The improved removal of AF dyes under UV irradiation was contributed to effective photocatalytic activity of well-distributed nano-TiO2 in nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel. Nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel could have a promising application in the treatment of dyes-containing effluents.

Highlights
Nano-TiO2/chitosan/poly(N-isopropylacrylamide) composite hydrogel was prepared by a two-step polymerization method. Nano-TiO2 was used to give the photocatalytic activity of the composite hydrogel. The composite hydrogel exhibited high efficiency of acid fuchsin dye removal rate under UV irradiation.

metadata.abstractText: Nano-TiO2/chitosan/poly(N-isopropylacrylamide) (nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm) composite hydrogel was prepared by a two-step polymerization method, and nano-TiO2 was used to give the photocatalytic activity of the composite hydrogel. The nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel was characterized by FT-IR and SEM. And its adsorption and photocatalytic degradation were investigated. The results indicated that dye adsorption was strongly influenced by solution pH and the acid fuchsin (AF) removal rate was maximum at pH=4. The composite hydrogel exhibited slightly decreased dye removal rate with increasing temperature, and the composite hydrogel containing AF dyes floated on the solution surface at 40 and could be readily removed from the aqueous solution. Kinetics analysis indicated that the dye adsorption by nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel obeyed pseudo-second order model. Moreover, nano-TiO2/CS/PNIPAAm composite hydrogel exhibited high efficiency of photocatalytic degradation for AF dyes, and AF dye removal rate reached 90.5% under UV irradiation for 160 min.
